reasoning: The critique largely does not engage the post’s core claim (whether compute bottlenecks prevent or substantially slow a software intelligence explosion); instead it highlights a second-order governance/organizational-risk implication of the post’s conditional scenario (“bottlenecks bite late”). That makes it weakly central: even if fully granted, it doesn’t refute the compute-bottleneck analysis or the conclusion that an SIE may proceed until late stages. As an attack on the narrower framing (“good news for SIE believers”), it’s a plausible but speculative causal story about incentives and corner-cutting under a sudden slowdown, with no concrete mechanism, evidence, or comparison to alternative dynamics (e.g., slowdown reducing race pressure). Most statements are conditionals and broadly reasonable, so correctness is fairly high. It is clearly stated, focused on one issue, and contains little filler.
title: Sudden compute bottlenecks after rapid progress may trigger dangerous corner-cutting
